content: There are extra trailing characters in the input of Micro World Test. Please fix it. Thanks. :)
"Who kneads that ?" -> you get an upvote for the pun. Brilliant.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this puzzle in the easy category even if personally I would have classified it as a clash.
However the other comments seem to be ok for the easy category.
There are many tests and the statement is clear.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, well done! 
Backstory is clear and written in good style.  I highlight the abundant number of test cases - other contributors should follow this...
I also learned a new English word ("frugal")

I solved it with recursion, seeing only afterwards from the sample solution that it can be simpler than that! :-) But this makes the puzzle even better.

Overall, it looks ok for an easy puzzle (especially when I didn't notice the "elegant" solution and I wrote the loop); I still have some nitpicks though:
 - it is irrelevant that measurements are in inches
 - as far as I know, "cut-out" shouldn't be hyphenated here

the problem as it is is fun, but seems to be too easy for a classical puzzle, doesn't it?
I think clash of code suits it better

Cool one. No typos nor bugs found.

Now I was thinking how would it be if you were to add the next generation of frugal AI bakers that will not be constrained by "grid-style orderly" cuts (more frugal in the sense that they would need to group up less dough on each iteration). One would have to:
- Find the centre of each biscuit cut this way...
- Find the minimal number of rounds to get the same result of the frugal baker.

nb: Don't do this at home, it's an open problem lol... https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circle_packing_in_a_square
http://hydra.nat.uni-magdeburg.de/packing/csq/csq.html

* Please format variables as [[variables]] instead of {{constants}} in all sections.

* Input section does not agree with stub generator: will the puzzle provide a string of two doubles or two doubles? If the former case, please revise Input section; if the latter case, please revise the stub generator.

Thanks.

Thanks as always. :)

I think I changed the input section correctly, but for whatever reason this part is still a challenge for me.  Can you please look again, and see.
ha, yes.  The "Frugal and Lazy" AI Baker problem is way more complex than one might think.

Thank you, and I do see your point, but....
(1) Based on responses from my friends who tried to code this, I think a lot of people will try to make this harder than it is (recursion, etc), so it really teaches "strive for simplicity" like "Robot Show" (https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/robot-show) does
(2) I love the banner image — which helps describe the situation/action.  And it’s also got an “organic vibe” — which is unusual in programming ;)

Thank you for the approval, and for the suggestions:

It's not relevant per se (to solve) that the measurements are in inches, but it makes the scenarios in the test cases "come to life".  You can picture a DoughSquare that's 30 inches and imagine a 3 inch biscuit -- that makes sense.
And it makes me (hopefully you too) giggle when I imagine the more absurd ones like a 0.2 inch biscuit (why bother!!) or a DoughSquare that is over 8 feet wide (I'm gonna need a bigger kitchen table!!)

I agree that technically cut out probably should be two words, but my thinking was that hyphenating it made it easier to read.  At least that's how I read things: When something is hyphenated I read it as one word.  And a biscuit cutter doesn't really cut (as one normally thinks of scissors or a knife cutting) ; it "cuts out".
Without the hyphen, the phrase "a Frugal Baker cut out than a Wasteful Baker" becomes clumsy ("cut out than") and I wanted to avoid that.

I definitely see your points, but I think I will pass on making the changes.  Thanks again for you approval.

Thank you very much.

Frugal is a word not used nearly enough in my opinion :)
Thank you !!

Haha, thanks !!!
(Yes, I was pretty "proud of myself" for coming up with that)

Wow, I see that.
Okay, fixed now; thanks for letting me know.

Just curious: 
How did you discover that? 
Why did it work for so many testers and such?  
Is that like a problem in a few languages, but not most?

Often I copy the inputs offline and test my code offline. That was also the case this time and then I discovered the trailing characters.

I'm not sure how CodinGame handles the trailing characters. It seems that sometimes they cause issues in certain programming languages.

Whatever floats your boat then =)
P.S.
Banner is indeed very nice
I think you mean "whatever butters your biscuit" ;)
fwiw, I agree the difficulty better suits an easy puzzle rather than a clash of code, as the thought required for the frugal calculation is greater than 90% of CoC questions.

You may refer to the examples here:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/stub-generator

Do you mean:
read side:float diameter:float
? Usually we wouldn't want splitting to be part of the exercise unless it is intended. If the above stub generator works as per your intention, then Input section becomes:
<<Line 1:>> Two floats [[side]] and [[diameter]] separated by a space

Hope this helps :)

Thanks.  I've made the change as suggested.

My skepticism re floats was that my understanding was that "doubles were always better".
So I honestly have never used floats for anything, but they seem compatible with Math.PI and all the case-answers remain the same, so okay.... I learned something :)

Thank you :D
I suggested "float" because that seems to be the only option provided by the stub generator. Just now I have tried testing using "double" and the stub generator throws an error "Invalid type 'double'". :shrug:
